subject: RE: [junit] Testing package private classes
msgSnippet: ... I believe this is not only a radical advice, it actually goes against the idea of unit testing.  What you are describing is acceptance testing, not unit
messageBody:
Rusty Harold writes:

> Don't do this directly. All unit tests should pass through
> the public (and protected) interfaces of a class. Most code
> that can't be reached through the public/protected interfaces
> is unreachable code and should be deleted rather than tested.

I believe this is not only a radical advice, it actually goes against the
idea of unit testing. What you are describing is acceptance testing, not
unit testing.

Unit testing allows you to test very small portions of code in order to
catch failures as soon as possible. If all you test is public/protected
methods, you will miss an opportunity to catch a bug in a very fundamental
piece of your code and you will be wasting time looking for it.

For example, imagine you are writing a file manager that can list your files
in several orders (by date, by name, etc...) and therefore, makes use of
several types of algorithms, all private. One day, the program starts
showing the files in the wrong order.

The sort algorithm is not exposed to anyone, but if you unit-test it, you
will catch the error much earlier instead of starting to investigate, say,
your list widget.

Don't be dogmatic about testing: test whatever you think can break. And
it's okay if it includes private methods.
